facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 127 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 47 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 127 of 1966 Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 11, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 47 of 1962. T. Desai, A. N. Kirpal and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: This appeal arises out of proceedings for registration of the firm Juggilal Kamalapat, Calcutta under section 26A of the Income Tax Act for the assessment year 1943-44.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of proceedings for registration of the firm, Juggilal Kamalapat, Calcutta, under section 26A ,of the Income Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  for the assessment year 1943-44.

facts.text: Prior to assessment year 1943-44, three Singhania brothers Sir Padampat Singhania, Kamlapat Singhania and Lakshmipat Singhania carried on hosiery business in name of Messrs. Juggilal Kamalapat with Head Office at Kanpur and branch at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to this assessment year, the three Singhania brothers, Sir Padampat Singhania, Kamiapat Singhania and Lakshmipat Singhania, were carrying on a hosiery business in the name of Messrs. Juggilal Kamalapat with Head Office at Kanpur and a branch at Calcutta.

facts.text: On November 29, 1939, three brothers executed a deed of partnership taking Jhabbarmal Saraf as partner with equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: On November 29, 1939, these three brothers executed a deed of partnership, by which one Jhabbarmal Saraf was taken in as a partner, and under this deed, all the four partners had equal shares.

facts.text: On October 27, 1941, three brothers executed Kamla Town Trust deed for welfare of employees of Juggilal Kamalapat Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd., becoming first trustees.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, .1941, the three brothers executed a trust deed known as the Kamla Town Trust, the principal object of which was the welfare of the employees of Juggilal Kamalapat Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. Under this deed, the three brothers became the first trustees.

facts.text: On December 2, 1942, three brothers executed Deed of Relinquishment relinquishing rights to all properties and assets of firm Juggilal Kamalapat in favour of Jhabbarmal Saraf and themselves as trustees of Kamla Town Trust, recognizing earlier oral relinquishment from March 26, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On December 2, 1942, a Deed of Relinquishment was executed by the three brothers, relinquishing their rights and claims to all the properties and assets of the firm, Juggilal Kamalapat, in favour of Jhabbarmal Saraf and of themselves in the capacity of the three first trustees of the Kamla Town Trust. This relinquishment deed purported to recognise an earlier oral relinquishment which was stated as having been operative with effect from March 26, 1942.

facts.text: On December 1, 1942, Partnership Deed executed between Jhabbarmal Saraf and three trustees of Kamla Town Trust, constituting partnership effective from March 27, 1942, with shares Kamla Town Trust 12 annas and Jhabbarmal Saraf 4 annas.

anchor.surface_text: On December 1, 1942, a Partnership Deed was executed between Jhabbarinal Saraf and the three trustees, by which they purported to companystitute a partnership firm taking effect from March 27, 1942, the two partners in the firm being Jhabbarmal Saraf and the Kamla Town Trust represented by these three trustees. The shares of the two partners in this partnership were Kamla Town Trust As. /12/-, and Jhabbarmal Saraf As. /4/-

facts.text: Firm Juggilal Kamalapat owned movable and immovable properties at Belur near Calcutta, including lands and buildings for hosiery factory, shown in balance-sheet as firm properties, with expenses and depreciation claimed.

anchor.surface_text: The firm, Juggilal Kamalapat, which had been carrying on the business of hosiery, owned both movable and immovable properties at Belur near Calcutta. The immovable properties companysisted of lands and buildings companystructed for the use of the factory for manufacturing hosiery, and they were shown in their balance-sheet as properties belonging to the firm. The firm had also been showing expenses incurred for maintaining or making additions or alterations to these buildings in their accounts and had been claiming depreciation in respect of them.

facts.text: New partnership applied for registration under s.26A for 1943-44, rejected by Income-tax Officer who noted Rs.50,000 introduced by Trust.

anchor.surface_text: It was in these circumstances that the new partnership, purporting to companysist of the Kamla Town Trust and Jhabbarmal Saraf, applied for registration under s. 26A of the Act for the assessment year 1943-44. The Income-tax Officer rejected this claim and, in doing so, also took numberice of the fact that a sum of Rs. 50,000/- had been introduced into this partnership firm by the Trust.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO order for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of the Income-tax Officer for reasons given by him which were different from those given by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld rejection of registration mainly because Relinquishment Deed dated December 2, 1942 was unregistered and could not transfer immovable properties.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld the order rejecting the application for registration under s. 26A on the main ground that the Relinquishment Deed dated 2nd December 1942, being an unregistered document, companyld number legally transfer rights and title to the immovables owned by the firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and that the transfer of the immovable properties being thus legally ineffective and they being number separable from the other business assets, the entire business of the firm was number legally transferred in favour of the Kamla Town Trust.

facts.text: Tribunal also noted new firm constitution not notified to banks and new partnership not registered with Registrar of Firms till May 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Two other reasons were also given that the companystitution of the new firm was number numberified to any of the Banks with which the old firm was dealing, and the new partnership was number got registered with the Registrar of Firms till May, 1946.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Calcutta High Court: Whether partnership as per Deed of December 1, 1942 legally came into existence and should be registered.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, at the request of the respondent firm, Juggilal Kamalapat, the following question was referred by the Tribunal or opinion to the Calcutta High Court- Whether on the above facts and in the circumstances of this case, the partnership, as evidenced by the Deed of 1 st December 1942, legally came into existence and as such should be registered?

facts.text: Calcutta High Court remanded case twice to Tribunal for supplementary statements as facts on genuineness not properly found.

anchor.surface_text: When this reference came up before the High Court on two different occasions, the High Court sent back the case for submission of further statements of the case to the Tribunal, because the High Court felt that facts, necessary to hold whether the respondent firm claiming registration was a genuine firm or number, had number been properly found by the Tribunal in its appellate order.

facts.text: High Court answered that regard being had to admissions by department and facts in para 6 of statement dated March 13, 1952, no legal flaw in constitution of partnership per deed of December 1, 1942, it came into existence, no impediment to registration.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of the reference by giving the following answer- Regard being had to the admissions made on behalf of the department, the facts and circumstances mentioned in paragraph 6 of the statement of case dated 13th March 1952 do number show that there was any legal flaw in the companysti- tution of the partnership firm as evidenced by the deed of 1st December, 1942. Upon such evidence, it must be companycluded that it did companye into existence and there is numberimpediment to its registration under Section 26A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appeal brought by Commissioner of Income-tax against High Court answer on certificate under section 66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been brought up by the Commissioner of Income-tax against this answer returned by the High Court on certificate under section 66A 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Kamla Town Trust introduced Rs. 50,000 as capital in the partnership firm.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected this claim and, in doing so, also took numberice of the fact that a sum of Rs. 50,000/- had been introduced into this partnership firm by the Trust.

facts.text: Tribunal found Kamla Town Trust constituted with three Singhania brothers as trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that a Kamla Town Trust had been companystituted of which the three Singhania Brothers were the Trustees.

facts.text: Tribunal found deed of partnership executed constituting firm Juggilal Kamalapat with Kamla Town Trust and Jhabbarmal Saraf, shares specified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also found that a deed of partnership was executed so as to companystitute the firm Juggilal Kamalapat, companysisting of two partners, the Kamala Town Trust, represented by the three trustees, and Jhabbarmal Saraf. Their shares in the profits and losses were also specified in the deed of partnership.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Deed of Relinquishment did not require registration as it transferred individual interest in partnership assets including immovables.

anchor.surface_text: The Deed of Relinquishment, in this case, was in respect of the individual interest of the three Singhania Brothers in the assets of the partnership firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and companysequently, did number require registration, even though the assets of the partnership firm included immovable property, and was valid without registration.

facts.text: Even if relinquishment invalid for immovables, valid for movables, partnership valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, we think that, even if it had been accepted that this deed of relinquishment required registration, that would number lead to the companyclusion that the partnership seeking registration was number valid and had number companye into existence in law.

issues.text: Whether on the above facts and in the circumstances of this case, the partnership, as evidenced by the Deed of 1st December 1942, legally came into existence and as such should be registered?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the above facts and in the circumstances of this case, the partnership, as evidenced by the Deed of 1 st December 1942, legally came into existence and as such should be registered?

issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, can the non-registration of Relinquishment Deed invalidate the transfer of the business assets to the new partnership?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, can the non-registration of Relinquishment Deed invalidate the transfer of the business assets to the new partnership ?

issues.text: Can the registration application be rejected merely on the ground that the business assets were not legally transferred to the new partnership?

anchor.surface_text: and Can the registration application be rejected merely on the ground that the business assets were not legally transferred to the new partnership ?

issues.text: Whether a reference to the High Court under section 66 lies only on a question of law and not on a question of fact regarding the factual existence of the partnership?

anchor.surface_text: A reference to the High Court lies only on a question of law. The High Court, when requested to answer the question referred in the first statement of the case, should, therefore, have confined itself to the legal aspect of the existence of the partnership and should not have entered at all into the question whether the partnership had come into existence in fact or not.

issues.text: Whether the interest of a partner in partnership assets comprising movable as well as immovable property should be treated as movable or immovable property for the purposes of s. 17(1) of the Registration Act, 1908, such that the Deed of Relinquishment requires registration?

anchor.surface_text: learned counsel for the respondent firm brought to our notice a recent decision of this Court in Addanki Narayanappa and Another v. Bhaskara Krishnappa dead and thereafter his heirs, and Others 1 where the question that came up for consideration was whether the interest of a partner in partnership assets comprising of movable as well as immovable property should be treated as movable or immovable property for the purposes of s. 17 1  of the Registration Act, 1908.

issues.text: Whether, even if the Deed of Relinquishment required registration and is invalid for immovable properties, it is valid for movable assets due to severability, allowing the partnership to come into existence?

anchor.surface_text: The Deed of Relinquishment, in this case, was in respect of the individual interest of the three Singhania Brothers in the assets of the partnership firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and consequently, did not require registration, even though the assets of the partnership firm included immovable property, and was valid without registration. ... The deed could clearly be divided into two separate parts, one relating to immovable properties, and the other to movable assets and the part of the deed dealing with movable assets could not be held invalid for want of registration.

arguments.claim: The Relinquishment Deed dated 2nd December 1942, being an unregistered document, could not legally transfer rights and title to the immovables owned by the firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and the transfer of the immovable properties being thus legally ineffective and they being not separable from the other business assets, the entire business of the firm was not legally transferred in favour of the Kamla Town Trust.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld the order rejecting the application for registration under s. 26A on the main ground that the Relinquishment Deed dated 2nd December 1942, being an unregistered document, could not legally transfer rights and title to the immovables owned by the firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and that the transfer of the immovable properties being thus legally ineffective and they being not separable from the other business assets, the entire business of the firm was not legally transferred in favour of the Kamla Town Trust.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deed transfers individual partner's interest treated as movable property, no registration required per precedent; alternatively severable.

arguments.claim: The firm seeking registration, consisting of the Kamla Town Trust and Jhabbarmal Saraf, was not a genuine firm and had never come into existence.

arguments.claim: On these facts (Kamla Town Trust constituted, deed of partnership executed with shares specified, Rs.50,000 introduced as capital), a valid partnership had come into existence.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that a Kamla Town Trust had been constituted of which the three Singhania Brothers were the Trustees. The Tribunal also found that a deed of partnership was executed so as to constitute the firm Juggilal Kamalapat, consisting of two partners, the Kamala Town Trust, represented by the three trustees, and Jhabbarmal Saraf.

arguments.claim: No provision of law or decision requires registration of deed of relinquishment by partners in respect of their share in firm owning immovables.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the deed of relinquishment is concerned, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the Commissioner has not been able to show to us any provision of law, or any decision of a Court laying down that a deed of relinquishment executed by partners of a firm in respect of their share and interest in a firm required registration, in case the firm owned immovable properties.

arguments.claim: Interest of a partner in partnership assets comprising movable and immovable property is movable property for s.17(1) Registration Act; transfer does not require registration.

anchor.surface_text: learned counsel for the respondent firm brought to our notice a recent decision of this Court in Addanki Narayanappa and Another v. Bhaskara Krishnappa dead and thereafter his heirs, and Others 1 where the question that came up for consideration was whether the interest of a partner in partnership assets comprising of movable as well as immovable property should be treated as movable or immovable property for the purposes of s. 17 1  of the Registration Act, 1908.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court follows and applies the precedent.

arguments.claim: Deed of Relinquishment was in respect of individual interest of three Singhania Brothers in partnership assets in favour of Kamla Town Trust; did not require registration even though assets included immovables; valid without registration.

anchor.surface_text: The Deed of Relinquishment, in this case, was in respect of the individual interest of the three Singhania Brothers in the assets of the partnership firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and consequently, did not require registration, even though the assets of the partnership firm included immovable property, and was valid without registration.

arguments.claim: Even if deed of relinquishment required registration, invalid only for immovables but valid for movables as separable; does not invalidate partnership.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, we think that, even if it had been accepted that this deed of relinquishment required registration, that would not lead to the conclusion that the partnership seeking registration was not valid and had not come into existence in law.

arguments.claim: Deed of relinquishment is in nature of deed of gift; properties separable, invalidity of one does not affect others (unlike partition).

anchor.surface_text: A deed of relinquishment is in the nature of a deed of gift, where the various properties dealt with are always separable, and the invalidity of the deed of gift in respect of one item cannot affect its validity in respect of another.

holdings.text: A reference to the High Court under section 66 lies only on a question of law and not on a question of fact regarding the factual existence of the partnership; the High Court erred in remanding the case twice to the Tribunal for factual findings on genuineness.

anchor.surface_text: A reference to the High Court lies only on a question of law. The High Court, when requested to answer the question referred in the first statement of the case, should, therefore, have confined itself to the legal aspect of the existence of the partnership and should not have entered at all into the question whether the partnership had come into existence in fact or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's reference of the question implies no adverse factual finding on existence; s.66 limits High Court to legal questions, factual findings by Tribunal are final.

holdings.text: The respondent firm did in fact come into existence, and the question before the High Court was only whether it came into existence legally.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, we must reject the submission made on behalf of the Commissioner that, in this case, the High Court should have gone into the question of existence of the respondent firm as a question of fact and in this appeal also, we must proceed on the basis that the respondent firm did in fact come into existence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's framing and reference of legal question on existence precludes challenge to factual existence under s.66.

holdings.text: On the facts found by the Tribunal (Kamla Town Trust constituted with three trustees, partnership deed executed with specified shares, Rs.50,000 introduced as capital), a valid partnership came into existence.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that a Kamla Town Trust had been constituted of which the three Singhania Brothers were the Trustees. The Tribunal also found that a deed of partnership was executed so as to constitute the firm Juggilal Kamalapat, consisting of two partners, the Kamala Town Trust, represented by the three trustees, and Jhabbarmal Saraf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's findings on trust, deed, shares, and capital contribution suffice for valid partnership without needing transfer of old firm's assets.

holdings.text: No provision of law or decision requires registration of a deed of relinquishment executed by partners in respect of their share and interest in a firm even if the firm owned immovable properties.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the deed of relinquishment is concerned, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the Commissioner has not been able to show to us any provision of law, or any decision of a Court laying down that a deed of relinquishment executed by partners of a firm in respect of their share and interest in a firm required registration,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner unable to cite any law or precedent mandating registration; relies on general findings.

holdings.text: The interest of a partner in partnership assets comprising movable as well as immovable property is movable property for purposes of s.17(1) Registration Act; the Deed of Relinquishment transferring individual interest of partners did not require registration and was valid without it.

anchor.surface_text: The Deed of Relinquishment, in this case, was in respect of the individual interest of the three Singhania Brothers in the assets of the partnership firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and consequently, did not require registration, even though the assets of the partnership firm included immovable property, and was valid without registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Addanki Narayanappa: partner's interest ceases to be exclusive property, becomes partnership asset; treated as movable regardless of asset composition.

holdings.text: Even if the Deed of Relinquishment required registration and was invalid for immovable properties, it was valid for movable assets as the deed is separable (unlike partition deeds); invalidity of one part does not affect the other.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, we think that, even if it had been accepted that this deed of relinquishment required registration, that would not lead to the conclusion that the partnership seeking registration was not valid and had not come into existence in law. The deed of relinquishment could, at best, be held to be invalid in so far as it affected the immovable properties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed of relinquishment akin to gift deed where properties are separable without inter-adjustment; cites Madras HC precedent; movables validly transferred plus capital contribution suffices for partnership.

holdings.text: The partnership as evidenced by the Deed of 1st December 1942 legally came into existence and there is no impediment to its registration under section 26A.

anchor.surface_text: Regard being had to the admissions made on behalf of the department, the facts and circumstances mentioned in paragraph 6 of the statement of case dated 13th March 1952 do not show that there was any legal flaw in the constitution of the partnership firm as evidenced by the deed of 1st December, 1942. Upon such evidence, it must be concluded that it did come into existence and there is no impediment to its registration under Section 26A of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court answer based on Tribunal facts, admissions, and legal validity of documents; rejects Tribunal's grounds on registration and transfer.

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in Ajudhia Pershad Ram Pershad v. Sham Sunder and Others   held that the interest in a partnership of a partner is to be regarded as movable property when it is sought to be dealt with under 0 . 21 r. 49, Civil Procedure Code, numberwithstanding that at the time when it is charged or sold, the partnership assets include immovable property.

precedents.case_name: Ajudhia Pershad Ram Pershad v. Sham Sunder
precedents.cited_proposition: interest in a partnership of a partner is to be regarded as movable property notwithstanding that partnership assets include immovable property
precedents.cited_holding: the interest in a partnership of a partner is to be regarded as movable property when it is sought to be dealt with under O.21 r.49 CPC notwithstanding partnership assets include immovable property

precedents.citation: Perumal Ammal v. Perumal Naicker Anr.  1

anchor.surface_text: This view was expressed by the Madras High Court in Perumal Ammal v. Perumal Naicker Anr.  1  A deed of relinquishment is in the nature of a deed of gift, where the various properties dealt with are always separable, and the invalidity of the deed of gift in respect of one item cannot affect its validity in respect of another.

precedents.cited_proposition: deed of relinquishment or gift is separable and invalidity in respect of one item does not affect validity in respect of another

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.

outcome.relief_summary: Deed of relinquishment valid; partnership legally constituted with ownership of movable assets and capital contribution, entitled to registration under s. 26A

anchor.surface_text: A reference to the High Court lies only on a question of law. The High Court, when requested to answer the question referred in the first statement of the case, should, therefore, have confined itself to the legal aspect of the existence of the partnership and should not have entered at all into the question whether the partnership had come into existence in fact or not.

In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, we must reject the submission made on behalf of the Commissioner that, in this case, the High Court should have gone into the question of existence of the respondent firm as a question of fact and in this appeal also, we must proceed on the basis that the respondent firm did in fact come into existence,

In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that a Kamla Town Trust had been constituted of which the three Singhania Brothers were the Trustees. The Tribunal also found that a deed of partnership was executed so as to constitute the firm Juggilal Kamalapat, consisting of two partners, the Kamala Town Trust, represented by the three trustees, and Jhabbarmal Saraf.

In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the deed of relinquishment is concerned, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the Commissioner has not been able to show to us any provision of law, or any decision of a Court laying down that a deed of relinquishment executed by partners of a firm in respect of their share and interest in a firm required registration,

In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.
was that a deed, evidencing the transfer of an interest of a partner in partnership assets, does number require registration even though the partners

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers the issue by stating 'The interest of a partner... is movable property for purposes of s.17(1)', matching the issue's question on classification for s.17(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Deed of Relinquishment, in this case, was in respect of the individual interest of the three Singhania Brothers in the assets of the partnership firm in favour of the Kamla Town Trust, and consequently, did not require registration, even though the assets of the partnership firm included immovable property, and was valid without registration.

In the case before us, therefore, the deed of relinquishment was valid at least in respect of movable properties, and the partnership seeking registration, thus, became owner of all the movable assets of the partnership in addition to having contributed a sum of Rs. 50,000/- as capital investment in it.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, we think that, even if it had been accepted that this deed of relinquishment required registration, that would not lead to the conclusion that the partnership seeking registration was not valid and had not come into existence in law. The deed of relinquishment could, at best, be held to be invalid in so far as it affected the immovable properties

anchor.surface_text: Regard being had to the admissions made on behalf of the department, the facts and circumstances mentioned in paragraph 6 of the statement of case dated 13th March 1952 do not show that there was any legal flaw in the constitution of the partnership firm as evidenced by the deed of 1st December, 1942. Upon such evidence, it must be concluded that it did come into existence and there is no impediment to its registration under Section 26A of the Income-tax Act.
